rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: RPS for this query or overall RPS increased significantly and DB is not able to process increased load

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check RPS graph for this query
Check YSQL RPS graph

rcaGuidelines.possibleCause: Response size or queried tables sizes increased significantly
rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: DB have to process more data to process each request, hence latency grows

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check Average Rows graph for the query
Check Table SST/WAL size graphs for tables, referenced in the query

rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: DB updated query execution plan based on the data statistics collected for requested tables

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check query execution plan via EXPLAIN ANALYSE

rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: RPC queues are growing and DB is not able to process all the requests on time. Typically all queries latency will grow.

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check RPC Queue Size graph

rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: DB nodes face CPU, Memory or Disk IOPS/throughput limits. Typically all queries latency will grow.

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check CPU, Memory and Disk IOPS/throughput graphs

rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: Network latency between DB nodes increased, Disk IOPS/throughput degraded, Network partitioning or other outage

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check network latency between the DB nodes
Check all DB nodes are up and running
Check Network graphs for anomaly

rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: DB nodes clock became out of sync, which slows down queries processing

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check Clock Skew graph

title: Uneven CPU usage distribution across DB nodes

rcaGuidelines.possibleCause: DB node(s) are processing more queries
rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: Particular DB node or set of nodes are processing significantly more requests, that the other nodes

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check YSQL RPC distribution across DB nodes
Check TServer read/write requests distribution across DB nodes

rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: Some DB background activities are consuming CPU unevenly

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check TServer/Master logs for evidence of background activities

rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: Some process(es) are running on the DB nodes which consumes CPU

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check top command output on the affected DB nodes

title: Uneven TServer Reads/Writes distribution across DB nodes

rcaGuidelines.possibleCause: DB node(s) are storing data, accessed more often
rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: Data for particular table/set of tables is partitioned across DB nodes the way that particular node gets more read/write requests consistently

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check reads/writes for particular tables too see - which table is causing uneven distribution
Check affected tables partitioning logic - maybe there is a better way to spread load across DB nodes

rcaGuidelines.possibleCause: Load balancing is not in progress or load is not balanced
rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: We can turn off load balancing during some DB operations. Also, load balancing may not be able to catch up on changed data, etc.

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check load balancing status in Master UI

title: Uneven distribution of YSQL queries across DB nodes

rcaGuidelines.possibleCause: DB clients prefer particular set of nodes
rcaGuidelines.possibleCauseDescription: DB clients have more connections to particular set of nodes, or are sending more queries to particular set of nodes

troubleshootingRecommendations.recommendation: Check if connecition count is even across DB nodes
Check query stats UI to see - which query/set of queries is distributed unevenly
